tossups.question: For ordinary differential equations in the complex plane, if the order of the poles at a singular point are sufficiently small, the point has this property, and thus there is a solution that can be written as a power series. Sturm-Liouville problems with this property have non-degenerate eigenvalues. In complex analysis, if there is an analytic continuation of a power series in a neighborhood of a point, then the point has this property. A closed set and a point not in that set can be (*) separated by neighborhoods in this kind of space, which the T3 axiom adds to a Hausdorff space. The Platonic solids are the only finite convex polyhedra with this property, since their faces are equivalent and have this property. For 10 points, name this word that describes a polygon with equal angles and equal side lengths.

This poet described being “prescribed rest in the mountains” due to his “torment of unjust sorrows” in the preface to a collection whose calmness he contrasted with the anger of his other poetry. The narrator of one of this author’s poems visits the vault of a suicide, stating “They say that she died of cold / But I know that she died of love.” This author, whose poems were adapted into a hit 1966 song for The Sandpipers by Pete Seeger, contrasted “the true friend / who offers his frank hand to me” and “the cruel one whose blows / break the heart by which I live” in “I Have a (*) White Rose to Tend.” This author described himself in another poem as “a sincere man” “from the land where the palm trees grow.” For 10 points, name this author whose Versos Sencillos provided the lyrics to “Guantanamera,” a nationalist poet from Cuba.

One of these entities is called extremal if a parameter symbolized kappa is equal to zero; that parameter relates differential changes in energy to changes in area of these entities. The ISCO radius is equal to three times another important measure for these entities. Convenient coordinates for describing these entities are named for Gullstrand and Painleve as well as (*) Kruskal and Szekeres. Varieties of these objects are described by the Reissner-Nordstrom and Kerr solutions of a set of field equations. These entities form above the TOV limit. They are completely characterized by their mass, electric charge, and angular momentum according to the no-hair theorem. For 10 points, name these things that contain gravitational singularities.

Troops were raised under General William McPherson to oppose an event in this state, whose participants sought to free prisoners after marching from Milford. Before a politician became the Secretary of the Treasury, he failed to prevent an event in this state while negotiating during the Redstone meetings. The perpetrators of a rebellion in this state were dismissed as country folks who couldn’t speak English in a pardon John (*) Adams issued to the co-conspirators of Fries’ Rebellion. Albert Gallatin failed to negotiate an end to a rebellion in this state. An army that was sent into this state was derisively nicknamed the “Watermelon Army,” and were led by “Light-Horse Harry” Lee and Alexander Hamilton while putting down a rebellion against a tax on spirits. For 10 points, name this U.S. state where the Whiskey Rebellion took place.

A character in this film says “We have to attack. If we don’t do that, we will lose every battle we are engaged in” while her husband is typing up a book. This film’s protagonist remembers a letter written to him by a girl who abandoned him after the war. This film’s protagonist hugs a woman made of sand on the beach after masturbating, and at the beginning of this film that character works as a mall (*) photographer. In a later scene in this film, its protagonist rides a motorcycle into the desert. While defending himself from “questions you already know the answer to,” one character in this film yells “pig fuck!” The alcoholic protagonist of this film is attracted to a group known as “The Cause,” who preach about reincarnation, and whose leader’s wife is played by Amy Adams. For 10 points, identify this Paul Thomas Anderson film in which a cult leader played by Philip Seymour Hoffman tries to recruit a character played by Joaquin Phoenix.

A cartoon subtitled “The Sound of Madness” features this political leader singing “So Long, Farewell”, etc. While in a lower political office, this leader replaced the crime combating SOCA with a new National Crime Agency which furthered this politician’s goals of cracking down on drugs like khat. A plan by this leader to increase internet surveillance to combat terrorism was decried by opponents as the “Snooper’s Charter.” This politician’s (*) chiefs of staff, Fiona Hill and Nick Timothy, resigned in the midst of some political compromising this politician made where they made Michael Gove environmental secretary. In a 2017 election called by this leader, dozens of legislative seats were gained by the Labour Party of Jeremy Corbyn, while this leader’s own party had to enter a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Union Party of Northern Ireland. For 10 points, name this current prime minister of Great Britain.

This character is unable to explain to his son why, along with hitting a golf ball, hearing the “sound of the rain in” a tree “had been the most religious experience of his life.” In a novella named for this character, his son and illegitimate daughter go to see American Beauty on New Year’s Eve. This character’s son chops down a beech tree that was used to shade his bedroom. This character has his first heart attack when his rented Sunfish capsizes and he thinks his granddaughter Judy has (*) drowned. After working as a linotypist, he becomes rich by inheriting a Toyota dealership. While drunk, this character’s wife Janice drowns their daughter in the bathtub. This native of Brewer, Pennsylvania was a high school basketball star. For 10 points, name this title character of a series of John Updike novels, whose titles follow his name with Run, Redux, Is Rich, and At Rest.
tossups.answer: “Rabbit” [or Harry Angstrom; or Harry Angstrom] <Ed. JO>

tossups.question: Bile salt-stimulated lipase is an enzyme produced in an important process in this organ. The drug trastuzumab emtansine is used to treat a disease of this organ by targeting proto-oncogene Neu [n-e-u] receptors. This organ is supported by Cooper’s ligaments, and Montgomery’s glands are found in this organ. The court case Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics, Inc. dealt with the legality of the (*) patent of a gene that causes a cancer of this organ, which is divided into ductal and lobular types. Tamoxifen is a drug that treats a cancer of this organ that is responsive to hormone therapy. BRCA1 and BRCA2 are genes responsible for cancer of this organ, treatment of which may involve a mastectomy. For 10 points, pink ribbons are used to raise awareness of cancers of what organ?

A composer from this country wrote a 9-movement suite for the bizarre combination of voice, alto flute, viola, guitar, vibraphone, xylorimba, and various drums. A piano piece by a composer from this country repeats a rhythmic motif of two eighth notes, two quarter notes, and then two half notes preceded by a grace note. A piano piece from this country opens with the left hand playing a G and then a beat later the right hand playing a B-minor chord. A composer from this country was influenced by a trip to (*) Brazil to write his ballet suite The Ox on the Roof. A composer from this country wrote a work for clarinet, violin, cello, and piano during his time in a German POW camp, while another is known for his Gnossiennes and Gymnopedies. For 10 points, name this home country of Olivier Messiaen, Erik Satie and Les Six.

During this event, the secret police were widely blamed for a deadly arson during a showing of the film The Deers at the Cinema Rex. The Communist Tudeh Party took a leading role in this event, and a possible compromise during this event was extinguished during the Black Friday massacre in Jaleh Square. In a failed attempt to stop this event, one leader forced a man from exile in (*) Najaf to the Neauphle-le-Château village near Paris. The SAVAK secret police were dissolved following this event. The success of this event was apparent in its enormous Muharram Protest, and its aftermath saw one side storm an American embassy and hold its employees hostage for 444 days. For 10 points, name this 1979 revolution that saw the dethronement of Muhammed Reza Shah Pahlavi by Ayatollah Khomeini.
tossups.answer: Iranian Revolution of 1979 [accept Iran after “revolution”; accept Islamic Revolution or Enqelāb-e Eslāmī] <Ed. JM>
tossups.answer_formatted: Iranian Revolution of 1979 <Ed. JM> [accept Iran after “revolution; accept Islamic Revolution or Enqelāb-e Eslāmī]

tossups.question: A popular excerpt from a text written by a leader of this religion translates as “When all possible means to secure justice fail / It is righteous to unsheath the sword.” That text, which takes the form of a 111-stanza letter written to an emperor, is included in this religion’s Book of the Tenth Emperor. This religion’s central text begins with a prayer that declares “sat nam,” after its opening line of “Ikk oan kar,” or “There is one (*) Being.” Some of the most important temples in this religion are the five takhts. This religion’s temples feature a copy of its holy book placed on a cot under a canopy, and a communal dining hall called a langar. Since 1708, the leader of this religion has been its holy book, the Adi Granth. For 10 points, name this religion founded in Punjab that counts Nanak and Gobind Singh among its gurus.

On the day she meets her lover for the first time, a character created by this author receives a bad omen when a flower from her crown falls onto the ground. That character, who appears in many of this author’s works including an adaptation of the legend of Floris and Blancheflour, was inspired by Maria d’Aquino. This author of The Elegy of Lady (*) Fiammetta dedicated his best-known work to women who are cooped up in the house all day. This author who inspired Chaucer’s “Franklin’s Tale” with his Filocolo also wrote about a marquis who stages a fake wedding to his 12-year-old daughter as part of a scheme to test his wife Griselda. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about seven women and three men telling stories during a plague outbreak in his Decameron.

The environmental art piece Niagara Gorge Path Relocated is a work of this type by Michelle Stuart, who is known for rubbing earth onto these things. Japanese works in this form are called emakimono, notably including four which depict anthropomorphic animals and one with scenes from the Tale of Genji. In one performance art piece, an extract from the book Cezanne, She Was a Great Painter was read off of an “interior” one of these things by Carolee Schneeman. Another artwork in this form has the Rainbow (*) Bridge at its centre and depicts Kaifeng in spring; that work was painted by Zhang Zeduan. For 10 points, long panoramas like Along the River During the Qingming Festival are in which format, intended to be viewed gradually as you unroll them?

In one story by this author, the protagonist purchases a bundle of letters from Mrs. Mogson, who turns out to be the title character in disguise. One of this author’s characters uses a little dog called Shan-Tung as the Nemean Lion in a story collection where he tries to complete twelve labours. Marlene Dietrich played Christine Vole in Billy Wilder’s film adaptation of one of this author’s stories. This author wrote story collections about a non-DC character named Harley Quin, as well as the recurring characters Parker Pyne and the married couple (*) Tommy and Tuppence. In a short story by this author, Sergeant Trotter uses skis to reach Monkswell Manor during a snowstorm. “Three Blind Mice” and “Witness for the Prosecution” were written by, for 10 points, what author who wrote a lot of short stories about Miss Marple and Hercule Poirot?

According to crystal field theory, this geometry can be considered an extreme version of the Jahn-Teller effect in which the d sub x squared minus y squared orbital has much higher energy than the others. If the crystal field stabilization energy is larger than the pairing energy, this low-spin geometry will be adopted by d8 compounds, which are often diamagnetic. A platinum-containing chemotherapy medication has this geometry, as does the first (*) binary noble gas compound discovered. Zeise’s salt and cisplatin contain a platinum atom with this geometry, which VSEPR [“vesper”] theory predicts for two lone pairs and four bonding pairs. For 10 points, name this geometry with symmetry d sub four h, which is exhibited by compounds like xenon tetrafluoride.
tossups.answer: square planar [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
tossups.answer_formatted: square planar [do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

tossups.question: An ambiguous portion of this document led to the 2004 Foreshore and Seabed Controversy, and an 1877 court case decided by James Prendergast ruled that this document was a “simple nullity” signed by “primitive barbarians.” The signing of this document is commemorated by a coat of arms that includes three ships and two (*) silver ferns. This document was signed by 540 rangatira, and was negotiated for one side by William Hobson after the successful sieges of several pa hillforts. A man who had previously cut down a flagpole, Hone Heke, was a prominent signer of this document. Legal issues created by this document’s sometimes erroneous Maori translation are still being resolved. For 10 points, name this treaty between Britain and New Zealand’s native people.

The beginning of Permian-Triassic extinction at the end of the Capitanian stage was marked by the eruption of the Emeishan traps in this province. The largest building in the world by floor space was opened in this province in 2013 and is named the New Century Global Centre. The Tianfu New Area in this province will be home to a new airport to reduce congestion at the nearby Shuangliu Airport. This province’s Wolong National Nature Reserve contains China’s national Giant (*) Panda Research Lab. The confluence of the Min and Dadu rivers in this province is the site of the largest Buddha statue in the world at Leshan. This province was China’s most populous until 1997 after Chongqing separated from it. For 10 points, name this province with capital at Chengdu that suffered a massive earthquake in 2008 and is the namesake of a popular spicy cuisine.

A notable explanation and clarification of this thinker’s ideas was given in a 1947 article by Rulon Wells. The developer of integrationism Roy Harris translated a work by this thinker and wrote a book about this thinker “and his Interpreters”. The so-called “sound images” formulated by this thinker refer to the mental process that created the entity. Some argue that Roland Barthes’ [BART’s] Mythologies draws on a system developed by this thinker to comment on the culture of the 1960s. This thinker, who said that language should be considered a social phenomenon(*), compared language to a symphony because of the difference between langue [“long”]-- or the system-- and parole [“pair roll”]. In his most famous work, this thinker described the arbitrary distinction between signifier and signified. For 10 points, identify this Swiss founder of semiotics best known for the posthumously-published Course in General Linguistics.

Description acceptable. During this event, Roger of Apulia described the “humiliation of women” and the genocidal tendencies of its perpetrators in the account Carmen Miserabile. During this event, many deaths resulted from the the Church of the Tithes collapsing under the weight of people standing on its balcony. Before this campaign’s decisive Battle of Sajo, King Bela IV made the disastrous decision to expel the (*) Cuman people from his realm. Nine sacks were filled with the right ears of many Polish knights during this campaign’s Battle of Liegnitz. This campaign was not completed due to the death of Ogedei Khan, though the strategic mind behind the main course of this campaign was Subotai. For 10 points, name this campaign led by Batu Khan into a continent containing Hungary and Poland.
tossups.answer: Mongol invasion of Europe [accept Mongol invasion of Hungary, Mongol invasion of Poland or other more specific answers involving the Mongols in Eastern Europe or Central Europe; prompt on answers such as Mongol invasion or invasion of Europe] <Ed. JM>
tossups.answer_formatted: Mongol invasion of Europe <Ed. JM> [accept Mongol invasion of Hungary, Mongol invasion of Poland or other more specific answers involving the Mongols in Eastern Europe or Central Europe; prompt on answers such as Mongol invasion or invasion of Europe]
acceptable: Mongol invasion of Hungary, Mongol invasion of Poland
other more specific answers involving the Mongols in Eastern Europe

tossups.question: This text argues that space and time can be divided infinitely many times, but this is not actually what occurs. The argument of change attributed to Parmenides is confronted in this work as part of the endoxa confronting its author. In chapter seven of this work, its author identifies the three princioples [“prin-see-oh-plays”] of substances, opposites, and privation. A bronze statue is discussed in this text to explain its author’s view on explanation and his four (*) causes including the material cause. Along with its author’s On the Heavens, Bertrand Russell said that “hardly a sentence” from this text can be accepted “in the light of modern science.” The eighth book of this work discusses the limits of the universe and the existence of a prime mover. For 10 points, what text by Aristotle deals with the philosophical underpinnings of natural and moving things and is usually contrasted with his Metaphysics?

(TB) The ‘B-A’ variety of a catalyst using this element is produced through precipitating this element’s chloride with aluminum instead of zinc dust, a more common preparation. There exists acid and base digested versions of a catalyst of this element named for Urushibara. The Sherritt process purifies cobalt by removing impurities of this element. A catalyst of this element is used in the second step of a reaction in which a dithiol is reacted with a carbonyl group, that is the (*) Mozingo reduction. A process that purifies this element creates a tetrahedral complex with four carbonyl groups. Hydrogenation catalysts that include this element, which is purified in the Mond process, include one named for Raney. Along with cobalt and iron, this element is ferromagnetic. For 10 points, name this transition metal with atomic number 28 and symbol Ni.

bonuses.leadin: This poet legendarily saved his magnum opus from a shipwreck by swimming to shore with the manuscript held over his head. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this author who wrote about Tethys falling in love with a European explorer in his home country’s national epic, The Lusiads.
Camões was from this country, whose highest literary prize he titles. Other authors from this country include José Maria de Eça de Queirós and Fernando Pessoa.

In the Lusiads, Vasco da Gama repels an attack from the Muslim ruler of this future Portuguese colony. Camões wrote part of his poem here, and Mia Couto, an ethnically Portuguese writer from this modern day country, won the Camões prize in 2013.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, give the following about chemicals used to clean pools.
parts: This ion is commonly added to pools to chlorinate them. Liquid bleach is a solution of this ion and sodium.

Cyanuric acid is added so that pools can stay chlorinated in sunlight. It exists as a tautomer, one with three hydroxyl groups, and the other with three of this functional group. This carbonyl-containing functional group is present in acetone.

Ions of this element are frequently added to pools to prevent algal growth, either directly through electrodes, or through addition of this element’s sulfate. This element’s sulfate is also used in the Bordeaux mixture, a common fungicide in vineyards.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about animals in Islam.
answers: the elephant [or fil; accept Year of the Elephant; or Amu L’Fil]
a dog [accept black dog specifically] <Ed. HB>
parts: This Arabic word, meaning “lawful,” often refers to rules about animals one can eat and how to slaughter them. This word is often contrasted with haram.
The year of Muhammad’s birth is known as the year of this animal, because one of these animals named Mahmud knelt and refused to go on while marching at the head of an army advancing on Mecca.

A weak hadith reports that in Medina, Muhammad ordered the killing of animals of this sort with spots over their eyes. Another hadith says that the Angels of Mercy do not enter a house where there are these animals or a picture of a living creature.
answers_formatted: the elephant [or fil; accept Year of the Elephant; or Amu L’Fil]

bonuses.leadin: In one test of this concept, a tachistoscope is used to display an array of letters and participants are asked to recall either the array or a single row. For 10 points each:
answers: speed reading [prompt on reading or skimming]
working memory [prompt on short-term memory] <Ed. HB>
parts: Name this form of visual memory that is high capacity but lasts for only a brief period of time. It supposedly plays a role in “change blindness.”
Tachistoscopes can also be used to display text in this technique, whose methods include eliminating subvocalization and chunking. Programs like Spritz may be used in this technique.

A model of human memory named after this type of memory was proposed by Alan Baddeley and Graham Hitch. According to that theory, this type of memory involves the “inner eye” and the “inner ear,” and it includes the temporarily available information the brain is using.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about mesothelioma. For 10 points each:
answers: simple squamous epithelia [prompt on a partial answer]
parts: Most mesothelioma cases are caused by exposure to these silicate minerals that form fibrous crystals. They were used in building insulation until it was found that their inhalation can lead to lung problems.

Mesothelioma commonly affects these structures and can cause buildup of fluid within their namesake cavity. The parietal one is attached to the thoracic cavity, while the visceral one lies on top of the lungs.

Mesothelium, the tissue type affected by mesothelioma, is this type of epithelial tissue. It consists of a single layer of flat epithelial cells and is used in places where fast diffusion is necessary, such as the capillaries and alveoli.

bonuses.leadin: After this man left a banquet because he “did not know how to sing” and went to sleep, a figure in his dream told him “you can sing for me . . . Sing me creation.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who sang a namesake “Hymn” about “the work of the Glory-Father,” which consists of creating “for the children of earth / heaven as a roof,” and “then middle-earth.”
“Caedmon’s Hymn,” the oldest surviving Old English poem, survived through manuscripts by this author. This “Venerable” monk also wrote the Ecclesiastical History of the English People.

Aldhelm, a contemporary of Caedmon and Bede, wrote a collection of these things called the Aenigmata. The “Leiden” one of these works, which is another of the earliest extant Old English poems, begins “The wet ground, incredibly cold, first produced me from its innards.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some creative uses for a certain ceremonial weapon. For 10 points each,
answers: speaker’s mace [prompt on mace; accept things like parliamentary mace, etc.]
parts: During an ethnically-tinged brawl between Nigerian legislators in 1962, an MP was clubbed with this object. In his “in the name of God, Go!” speech, Oliver Cromwell called this object a “fool’s bauble.”
The first PM of the Bahamas, Lynden Pindling, threw the mace into this body of water to stall debate, prompting a political crisis as divers looked for it.

In addition to having a cool mace, the Speaker of the British parliament also gets to sit in this special seat. Although it’s now basically a modified recliner, this seat’s name was far more literally defined in medieval times.
answers_formatted: speaker’s mace [prompt on mace; accept things like parliamentary mace, etc.]

bonuses.leadin: This slow aria begins with the quarter notes E-flat, D-flat, B-flat, A-flat, and is then repeated with a small flourish before the singer says she had never “harmed a living soul.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this soprano aria in which the singer contemplates her fate after Scarpia tells her the only way she can be with her lover is if she sleeps with Scarpia.
Vissi d’arte is sung by the title character from one of this composer’s operas. Other famous arias by this composer include “O Mio Babbino Caro” and “Nessun Dorma.”

The clarinet introduces this tenor aria from act 3 of Tosca, where Cavaradossi is unable to hold in his emotions as he attempts to write Tosca a letter. That clarinet introduction of this aria is later played in a passage marked triple-forte by the brass as Tosca commits suicide.

bonuses.leadin: The popular song "Dying of Hunger, Dying of Cold” was created by the leader of this event, which was inspired by the Jacobins and proto-socialist Sylvain Marechal. For 10 points each:
answers: Conspiracy of the Equals [or Conjuration des Égaux]
parts: Name this conspiracy during the French Revolution, led by Francois Babeuf against the Directory.

The Pantheon Club, many of whose members made up the Conspiracy of Equals, was earlier dissolved by this man as a way of preserving the Directory’s power. This man later overthrew the Directory on the 18th of Brumaire.
Babeuf, the conspiracy’s leader, was given this nickname for his resemblance to a reformist Roman tribune.

bonuses.leadin: In one myth, this god, one of whose counterparts is Raven, created death by throwing a rock into the water. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this trickster god from various southwest Native American mythologies.

In this tribe’s story about Coyote, Coyote has the ability to steal fain from Tó Neinilii. In this tribe’s creation myth, the First Man and First Woman pass from the blue Second World to the Third World where there are animals.

This word is the Navajo word for their homeland and, in their mythology, is the center of their “Story of the People” myth. The infant Changing Woman was supposedly found in this location by the Holy People.

bonuses.leadin: Year required. This event, the second largest of its kind, began after the FirstEnergy Corporation’s Eastlake facility shut down. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event that caused large areas of Ontario and the Northeastern United States to go without power for over two days during the presidency of George W. Bush.
After Akron, this other Ohio city was the first affected by the Blackout. This city’s mayor at the time was Jane Campbell, who addressed the lack of water services from its Cuyahoga River.

The Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 was repealed with the passage of this legislation, which was passed two years after the Blackout. This act set federal reliability standards regulating the electrical grid.

bonuses.leadin: Since it is aneutronic, the proton-boron reaction is a popular candidate for achieving a sustainable terrestrial version of this process. For 10 points each:
answers: nuclear fusion [do not accept or prompt on “(nuclear) fission”]
parts: Name this process. Unlike a similar process, it is harder to contain, and combines light nuclei instead of splitting heavy ones.

Cold fusion now has negative connotations, but one form of fusion which does take place at a reasonable temperature is fusion catalyzed by these particles. Since they are heavier than electrons, they bring the nuclei close enough together to promote fusion.
Since muons cost too much energy to produce, fusion must occur at high temperatures and densities to achieve this criterion which quantifies the conditions necessary for ignition.
answers_formatted: nuclear fusion [do not accept or prompt on "(nuclear) fission"]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some animals in Kalidasa’s play The Recognition of Shakuntala.
parts: King Dushyanta first meets Shakuntala when out hunting one of these animals. In the Ramayana, Sita is kidnapped using a plot in which the demon Maricha takes the form of a golden one of these animals.

After Shakuntala forgets to offer an old sage food, the sage casts a curse that causes Dushyanta to forget who she is. She’s unable to prove her identity because her ring slipped into a river and was eaten by one of these animals, known like Vishnu’s avatar of this type as matsya.
After finally realizing who his wife is, Dushyanta is given a tour of heaven. There, he encounters a boy who turns out to be his son playing with one of these animals.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about early archaeologists. For 10 points each:
parts: This German archeologist tried to prove that the classical epics were based off of real events by undertaking several excavations of Troy beginning in 1871, at which he uncovered the “Mask of Agamemnon.”

Heinrich Schliemann stole the thunder of this amateur archeologist, who had originally dug up and theorized Hisarlik to be the mythical city of Troy seven years before Schliemann came to the same conclusion.
Austen Henry Layard excavated several important sites of this ancient empire, which included the Library of Ashurbanipal and the cities of Nimrud and Nineveh.

bonuses.leadin: Though supposedly in A minor, this composer’s piece “Moro, lasso, al mio duolo” demonstrates his bizarre chromaticism by opening with a C-sharp minor chord. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian Renaissance composer. Stravinsky wrote a ballet named “Monumentum pro [this composer]”.

Gesualdo mostly composed pieces in this genre, the secular counterpart of the motet. Like some of Gesualdo's works in this genre, Michelangelo Rossi’s two books of pieces in this genre also contained a lot of chromaticism.
This other composer wrote 9 books of Madrigals, as well as operas such as The Coronation of Poppea and L’Orfeo.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points, name these minerals that can adopt a botryoidal habit, which means they are composed of a bunch of spheres that look like grapes.
parts: Chalcedony, a subtype of this mineral, can form purple botryoidal clusters that go by the trade name “grape agate.” This mineral is at the bottom of Bowen’s reaction series.
This other mineral can adopt a botryoidal habit with larger, more irregular, spheres. Along with magnetite, it is one of the main ores of iron.
This vibrantly green form of copper(II) carbonate is often found alongside azurite, and used for decoration and pigments. It is associated with limestone deposits.

bonuses.leadin: In the “Elegiac Conclusion” to the book which coined this group’s name, its six branches are said to be “Feminists, Marxists, Lacanians, New Historicists, Deconstructionists, Semioticians.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Western Canon: The Books and School of the Ages
parts: Name this group that, according to the man who coined its name, makes a “repeated insistence” that the “‘anxiety of influence’” does not apply “to women and to what we quaintly term ‘multiculturalists.’”
Harold Bloom railed against the School of Resentment and defended “Dead White European Males” like William Shakespeare in this 1994 book, subtitled “The Books and School of the Ages.”
In the “Elegiac Conclusion,” Bloom declared that ultimately, “the Western Canon is Shakespeare and” this Italian author of The Divine Comedy.
answers_formatted: The Western Canon: The Books and School of the Ages
acceptable: The Western Canon: The Books and School of the Ages
Western Canon: The Books and School of the Ages

bonuses.leadin: US Soccer failed to qualify for the World Cup, so sadly, that makes it a good target for jokes and quiz bowl questions. So answer some questions on the USMNT, for 10 points each.
answers: CONCACAF (or The Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football) <Ed. HB>
parts: Christian Pulisic, the attacking midfielder on the US team, currently plays for this German club. This club’s logo prominently features the letters “BVB” and it is the second largest club in Germany after Bayern Munich.
After losing the match, this manager resigned. He had earlier led the US during its 2002 World Cup run and had come back as USMNT manager after the firing of Jürgen Klinsmann in 2016.
The US lost to Costa Rica 4-nil in November 2016 while competing in this association. This association is currently the third most successful after UEFA and CONMEBOL. Acronym acceptable.
metadata: or The Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football

bonuses.leadin: In this philosopher’s The Moralists, the character Theocles mentions the author of “a certain fair Inquiry,” referring to this philosopher and his Inquiry Concerning Virtue and Merit. For 10 points each:
answers: Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury [accept either underlined name]
Cambridge Platonists [prompt on partial answers] <Ed. HB>
parts: Name this English philosopher, some of whose works were collected in the 1711 volume Characteristicks of Men, Manners, Opinions, Times.
According to Shaftesbury, his parents’ marriage was negotiated by this philosopher. He more famously discussed a tabula rasa in his Essay Concerning Human Understanding.

Shaftesbury compiled the sermons of Benjamin Whichcote into one of his early publications. Whichcote himself led this group named after a university, which included Henry More and tried to reconcile Christianity with Renaissance humanism.
answers_formatted: Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury [accept either underlined name]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about sculptures by Paul Gauguin.
parts: In his self-portrait in the form of a head-shaped jug, Gauguin depicted himself with a severed ear in reference to the self-mutilation of this fellow artist, who was his roommate in Arles.

Gauguin created a pair of anticlerical sculptures called Père Paillard and Thérèse to decorate his home in this French-administered island group, where he lived after leaving Tahiti. Gauguin is buried in the town of Atuona here.

Gauguin’s primitivist sculpture Oviri, which depicts a Tahitian goddess holding a wolf cub, is thought to have partly inspired the women in this 1907 painting, which was also influenced by El Greco’s Opening of the Fifth Seal.
